Dear Ms. McClain:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Youth has displayed self-harming/suicidal behaviors on multiple occasions since
January 2022 and the facility has not provided appropriate mental health evaluations
in response.
INVESTIGATION:
A complaint was received on 3/29/22 alleging on 1/12/22 Youth A tied a shoestring
around her neck and said she wanted to die. Youth A also had three superficial cuts
on her arm that were believed to have been self-inflicted. On 2/7/22 Youth A jammed
her door with a sock where staff were unable to gain entry and then took a cord from
her room and attempted to strangle herself with it. On 3/28/22 Youth A tied a cord
around her neck and expressed suicidal ideations. The facility did not seek a mental
health evaluation for Youth A after any of these incidents.
Interviews:
The Chief Administrator (CA) interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22 along
with the DHHS Worker. She reported after the 1/12/22 and 2/7/22 incidents Youth A
was placed on at risk precautions. The incident on Monday (3/28/22) the staff did not
call the therapist to have Youth A placed on at risk precautions.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22 along with the DHHS
Worker. She said things are good on the unit. She has no issues with staff or her
peers. She has no issues with the facility and likes being there. On Monday Youth A
took a string and put it around her head. Staff 4 pulled it tighter when she tried to
take it off Youth A. Youth A said she did not want to hurt herself. She said the string
was a cord from the TV. She only had it around her neck for 10 seconds. She said
the staff always stop her when she tries to hurt herself. She did not do anything else
to try and hurt herself. She did it because she did not get what she wanted. She was
in the milieu by the TV. Staff 3 and Staff 4 were there. Youth A said she is safe at
the facility. Whenever she does something like this, they process with her afterwards
and she meets with her therapist one time a week and a doctor every two weeks.
Youth A's therapist (Therapist) was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22
along with the DHHS Worker. Therapist thinks she was contacted regarding the
1/12/22 incident but could not recall specifically. She stated Youth A was not
suicidal, but she was placed on precaution just to be safe. Therapist reported Youth
A threatens self-harm as a form of attention seeking. Therapist has a Limited
License Master Social Worker (LLMSW). Therapist stated she is qualified to
determine if Youth A needs an further assessments following these incidents.
Therapist also could not recall the 2/7/22 incident. She reported at no time has
Youth A required outside mental health treatment. Youth A did not do anything that
4

left marks or actually tied anything around her neck. None of the incidents ever
resulted in a restraint. Staff direct Youth A to stop, and she stops. Youth A does
these things when she is told no.
Therapist stated, on Monday 3/28 she did not know that Youth A threatened to harm
herself until Tuesday. The staff should have called her, but they did not. She
believes they called Supervisor. This is the first time Therapist had concerns about
not being notified. Therapist completes her own assessment and uses a precaution
table to help make a decision to put the youth on precaution or not. Nine times out of
ten the youth will go on precaution just to be safe. She documents her assessment
on the Suicide precaution form. If she is at the facility, she will complete the form. If
she is not at the facility, staff will complete the form and she will sign it the next time
she is at the facility.
The Program Supervisor (Supervisor) was interviewed face to face at the facility
along with the DHHS Worker on 3/31/22. She reported on 3/28/22 the staff had
called her and updated her on what Youth A was doing. They were asking for help
with interventions. Youth A was targeting one staff. She told them to remove the
audience and the one staff. Youth A was threatening a peer and Staff 1. The staff
reported when Youth A went for a cord, Staff 3 stepped in and told her to stop, and
Youth A stopped. Youth A was de-escalated at that point. Supervisor did not know if
Youth A wrapped the cord around her neck. Staff 4 was a guest staff that night, so
Staff 3 stepped in to de-escalate. From Supervisor’s phone conversation she
interpreted that Staff 3 and Staff 4 knew what was going on and Youth A was not
suicidal. Youth A was targeting others. Youth A went for the cord, but Supervisor
could not say if Youth A was self-harming.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/13/22 along with the DHHS
Worker. She reported she was helping on Youth A's unit the night of 3/28/22. She
said Youth A was going around the unit saying she would hit Staff 1. Youth A was
upset because she was grounded and could not go to the Coffee House. Youth A
wrapped a cord around her neck, but Staff 4 got the cord before Youth A could pull it
tight. Staff 4 said she just grabbed the cord and Youth A let go. Staff 4 and Staff 3
de-escalated Youth A who stated she felt hopeless but not suicidal. Once Youth A
was de-escalated, she left and went back to her unit. She thought Staff 3 called the
therapist, but she was not sure.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/13/22 along with the DHHS
Worker. She reported she was present during an incident in February in which Youth
A tied a cord around her neck. She reported Youth A had got into a fight with Youth
B. Youth A was in her bedroom when she jammed a Croc in her door so it could not
be opened by staff. Youth A then tied something around her neck. Staff 3 processed
with Youth A. Youth A then let staff into her room. The on-call therapist was
contacted. Staff 2 stated she has rarely seen Youth A self-harm. If a youth is
displaying self-harming behaviors, then the staff are to contact the therapist, and the
5

youth is put on risk status. Staff take all potentially dangerous items from the youth’s
room and are monitored every 15 minutes.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/13/22 along with the DHHS
Worker. Staff 3 is a shift supervisor. On a Monday in March (3/28/22) Youth A was
upset because she could not go to the Coffee House. Staff 3 was in the office and
was called out of the office because Youth A had a cord around her neck. Youth A
was pulling on the cord, but not enough to hurt herself. Youth A was told to stop, and
she stopped. She did not think Youth A was suicidal. Staff 3 reported, another time it
was also a Monday, Youth A jammed her door shut with a Croc or something. She
tied something around her neck. Staff 3 could not recall any other details. Staff 3
said any time a youth tries to self-harm they call the on-call staff, the house
supervisor, and the nurse. Staff 3 said she was not the person to make the calls
either of the times she saw Youth A self-harming.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/14/22 along with the DHHS
Worker. She reported she was working on 3/28/22 but was in the office when Youth
A tried to hurt herself. She reported Staff 3 and Staff 4 were working with Youth A.
Staff 1 recalled a time when Youth A jammed her door closed. Staff 1 went to Youth
A to process with her but switched out with Staff 3. Staff 1 reported if a youth is
attempting to self-harm the staff process with them, encourage them to use their
coping skills, redirect the behavior, remove the object, call the on-call staff, the
Campus Supervisor, and the home supervisor.
The facility does not utilize video surveillance.
Documents Reviewed:
 Youth A’s case file in MiSACWIS was reviewed. Youth A was admitted to the
program on 10/11/21. She has a history of being verbally, physically, and
sexually aggressive, harming herself, lying, and running away.
 Staff 1’s employee file indicated she has been working at the facility since
2014. She has disciplines for lack of training hours, leaving a youth
unsupervised, inappropriate response to youth, and medication errors.
 Staff 2’s employee file indicated she has worked at the facility since 11/3/21.
She did not have any discipline action.
 Staff 3’s employee file indicated she has been working at the facility since
2017. She had two disciplines for not completing her annual training hours
and medication errors.
 Supervisor’s employee file stated she has been working at the facility since
2004. She had disciplines for not completing staff evaluations, not getting her
TB test timely, and not completing required training.
 Therapist’s social work license was viewed to be current.
 Incident Report from 1/12/22 stated Youth A was in her bedroom when she
wrote a note saying she was going to die. While in her room she tied a
shoestring to the doorknob with the other end held around Youth A's neck.
She was put on at-risk precautions and placed in an empty room. Youth A
6

reported she did this because she was tired of her peers talking bad about
her.
 Incident Report from 2/7/22 Youth A was upset about being grounded. She
went into her room, jammed the door closed with a sock, and put a cord
around her neck to choke herself. Youth A was placed on at risk precaution.
Staff processed with Youth A until she opened the door.
 Incident Report from 3/28/22 Youth A was upset that she could not go to the
Coffee House. Youth A took a cable from the television and attempted to
choke herself. Staff 3 attempted to stop Youth A. Youth A stopped and sat on
the floor. She processed with staff. Report does not say anything about at-risk
precautions. It is checked that the clinician was notified as well as the
supervisor.
 E-mail from Youth A’s Foster Care Worker (FCW) dated 2/15/22 indicated
Therapist did not think Youth A was suicidal.
 Suicide Precaution forms for 1/12/22 and 2/7/21 were reviewed. Youth A was
placed on precaution by Therapist both times. The facility did not have a form
for the 3/28 incident.
DHHS Case conference was held on 4/27/22 with the DHHS Worker who did not
have any findings.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and
behavioral health care.
ANALYSIS: Therapist is an LLMSW and is qualified to assess if Youth A is
suicidal. She did not determine Youth A was suicidal. Youth A
also stated she was not suicidal. Based on this information
further mental health care was not needed.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Facility is not adhering to a safety plan previously put in place to keep personal
belongings away from Youth A.
INVESTIGATION:
A complaint received on 3/29/22 alleged Youth A had a safety plan in place that
restricted her from having her personal belongings due to self-harm. Despite this
Youth A was still able to access items to harm herself with.
7

Interviews:
The Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22
along with the DHHS Worker. She reported Youth A did not have anything in her
room on 3/28/22 to harm herself. Youth A had taken a cord from the milieu TV. CA
reported the staff did not contact the therapist to report Youth A had attempted self-
harm on 3/28/22.
During Youth A’s face to face interview at the facility on 3/31/22 she reported she
took the cord she used to try to self-harm from the TV in the milieu.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22. She reported Youth
A has an Individual Program Modification (IPM) that says she cannot have cords.
She can be reassessed and come off the IPM if she is not displaying the same
behaviors. Therapist confirmed staff did not contact her about Youth A’s attempted
self-harm on 3/28/22.
When Supervisor was interviewed on 3/31/22 she reported the staff did not convey
to her that Youth A was trying to harm herself.
During Staff 1’s interview on 4/14/22 she reported she did not recall Youth A self-
harming on 3/28/22 as she remained in the office due to Youth A threatening her.
She did report if a youth is self-harming, they call the therapist, but she could not
recall if the therapist was called that night.
Staff 3 reported during her interview on 4/13/22 that the staff are supposed to
contact the therapist any time a youth attempts to self-harm, but she was not the
person to make that call on 3/28/31.
Staff 4 reported during her interview on 4/13/22 that she left after Youth A was de-
escalated on 3/28/22 so she did not know if the therapist was contacted.
A tour of the unit on 3/31/22 found Youth A did not have any cords or other
potentially dangerous items in her room. The cord to the TV was no longer attached
to the TV in the milieu.
Documents Reviewed:
 Youth A’s Individual Program Modification (IPM) states Youth A's room will be
stripped of all shoes, socks, clothes, cords, cables, and any other items that
may fit in the cracks of the door. This is to prevent Youth A from wedging the
door so staff cannot enter. This will also remove items she can tie around her
neck.
 Suicide precaution form: There was no suicide precaution form for 3/28/22.
 Incident Report from 3/28/22 written by Staff 1: Youth A took a cable from the
television and attempted to choke herself. Report does not say anything
8

about at-risk precautions. It is checked that the clinician was notified as well
as the supervisor.
 Suicide Prevention Policy: Staff members should never dismiss or minimize a
client’s suicidal thoughts or gestures.
 Suicide Prevention Procedures: Staff members are to contact the youth’s
Clinician, on-Call Clinician, or CA to determine at-risk status.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program statement which specifically addresses all of the
following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility was following Youth A’s Individual Modification
Program as she did not have any cords in her room. Rather she
took the cord from the milieu TV to wrap around her neck. No
violation established for this allegation.
The staff working on 3/28/22 did not follow the facility’s Suicide
Prevention Procedures. CA and Therapist both confirmed that
staff had not contacted Therapist as required.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

ALLEGATION:
Facility has violated another safety plan regarding Youth A being left unsupervised
with other youth.
INVESTIGATION:
The complaint received on 3/29/22 also alleged Youth A had a safety plan in place
to not allow her to have any unsupervised contact with the other youth. Despite this
on 2/25/22 it was alleged Youth A was alone with Youth B when Youth A touched
Youth B’s vagina.
Interviews:
The Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22.
She reported Youth A has a sexual safety plan but the two staff who were working
9

during the alleged incident were dealing with a crisis, so no one was watching Youth
A. Two of the other youth were fighting. Youth B walked out of the bathroom in just a
towel. Other staff were called to assist but they cannot always get to the unit right
away. CA reported they attempt to schedule a one-on-one staff for Youth A when
they can, but it is not always possible. They did not have a one-on-one for this
incident.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on 3/31/22. She was asked about
her sexual safety plan, and she said she was on it to keep her from "talking to
people." She said this meant trying to date people. She denied any touching
occurred with the other youth she wants to date. She said all she does is talk. Youth
A no longer wanted to be interviewed and asked to leave.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/13/22. She reported she
was in the shower when two of her peers were fighting. Youth A knocked on the
door to the shower. Youth B thought it was staff, so she opened the door. Youth A
grabbed Youth B, kissed her, and touched her under the towel. Youth B stated the
door to the hallway was closed at the time, so the youth were in the hallway by
themselves. Youth B said she was afraid Youth A would hurt her as she has hurt
Youth B in the past.
The Licensee Designee (LD) was interviewed face to face at the facility on 4/13/22.
She provided the incident report regarding the fight between Youth C and Youth F
during which Youth A touched Youth B sexually. The incident was first reported on
2/25/22 but the incident occurred on 2/15/22. Staff 5, Staff 6, Staff 7, Staff 8, Staff 9,
and Staff 10 were all listed on the incident report (This complaint was received by
the department but was initially dismissed as no rule violations were alleged).
Staff 8 was interviewed via telephone on 4/18/22. Staff 8 stated he is the Campus
Supervisor who responds to any crisis that occurs on campus. He could not recall
the incident on 2/15/22. He heard about Youth A touching Youth B but could not
recall how he heard.
Staff 5 was interviewed via telephone on 4/19/22. She reported she was called to
assist when Youth C and Youth F got into a fight. When she showed up on the unit,
she was asked to sit with Youth F in a conference room. She could not recall where
the other youth were located at that time.
Staff 6 was interviewed via telephone on 4/20/22. She reported she was working
when Youth C and Youth F got into a fight. She could not remember specifics about
where the other youth were during the fight but usually, they work to get the other
youth to go to their rooms or remove them from the unit. She thought the other youth
were down the hallway in their rooms. Youth F went down her hallway and the door
was closed behind her so Youth C could not get to her. The other hallway, where
Youth A and Youth B’s bedrooms where she believed was left open. Whenever the
youth are in their rooms the door to the hallway stays open. Staff 6 reported she and
10

Staff 10 could not separate the fighting two youth fighting and be supervise the
hallway at the same time. They called the campus supervisor, Staff 8, who came to
the unit to help within 5 minutes. Staff 6 stated they could see the hallway during the
fight. Youth B took a shower after the youth had calmed down. She did not know
where Youth A was when Youth B was in the shower. The staff always position
themselves so they can see the hallway. She does not believe there was any time
that Youth A could have touched Youth B. Youth B is pretty verbal and she would
have said something that evening.
Staff 7 was interviewed via telephone on 4/20/22. She reported she was getting
ready to leave her shift when she received word of a situation on Youth A's unit. She
went to the unit to help. When she got there the fight had already broken up. She
watched the other youth while Youth C and Youth F received medical attention.
When she got to the unit Youth A and Youth D were in the milieu. Youth B was in
her room. She did not see Youth B take a shower nor did she see Youth A go down
the hallway.
Staff 9 was interviewed via telephone on 5/2/22, She came to the unit the evening of
2/15/22 after Youth C and Youth F had already been separated. Youth C was off the
unit, Youth F was walking around, Youth B was in the office on the phone and all the
other girls including Youth A were sitting on the couches in the milieu. Staff 9 never
saw Youth B take a shower nor did she see Youth A and Youth B in the hallway
together.
Staff 10 was interviewed via telephone on 4/18/22. She reported she was working
when Youth C and Youth F got into a fight. Staff 10 and Youth F walked on the unit
and out of nowhere Youth C started to fight Youth F. Staff 10 and Staff 6 worked to
separate the two youth. They got them separated and sent Youth F to her room and
closed the hallway door so Youth C could not get to her. Staff 10 reported this was
the only hallway door that was closed. It was the smaller hallway and not the hallway
Youth A and Youth B resided in. She reported the door to the hallway Youth A and
Youth B were in was never closed that she saw. She did report someone else could
have closed it as she was busy dealing with Youth C and Youth F. When they got
Youth C and Youth F separated, they called the campus supervisor, Staff 8, who
came and took Youth C to a different unit. When the fight started the youth were all
in the milieu doing an activity. She could not remember if Youth B was in the shower
before or after the fight. She never saw Youth B enter the shower, but she did see
her exit and go to her room. Youth A did not want to stay in her room and was
continuously redirected for coming out. Staff 10 stated the doors in the hallway had
to have a key to enter but the youth could exit the doors without them being
unlocked by staff. Staff 10 never saw Youth A knocking on the bathroom door. No
one reported any touching that night. Youth A did not have a one-on-one that night
and Staff 10 did not think she needed one as Youth A was listening to the staff and
did not cause any problems. She reported Youth A only acts up with certain staff.
Documents Reviewed:
11

 MiSACWIS intake received 2/25/22: Last week 2/15/22, there was a physical
fight between two other residents in the building. Staff members were present
to deal with the fight. Youth B was in the shower and heard noises, so she
stepped out momentarily in a towel to see what was going on. When Youth B
stepped out of the shower, Youth A grabbed her by the towel, kissed her,
then touched Youth B's vagina. Though staff were present for the fight, and
Youth A and Youth B were within sight of the altercation, the staff were not
otherwise aware and did not see this occur. The sexually inappropriate
touching was not disclosed until today though there had already been a safety
plan in place before this incident.
 Incident Report Dated 2/25/22 reported the same information disclosed during
Youth B’s interview.
 Youth A’s sexual safety plan put in place on 1/18/22 and is reassessed every
30 days, states: Youth A will not be left unattended with another client 1:1 or
in any confined space or small room that does not present staff with clear
opportunity to monitor the situation unless a staff member is directly
monitoring the interaction; and Staff will exercise vigilance and continual
monitoring to assure the safety of peers.
 Youth B’s case file indicates she was admitted to the program on 7/14/21.
She has a history of suicidal ideation, non-suicidal self-harm, running away,
and substance abuse.
 Youth B’s sexual safety plan initiated on 12/9/21 was the same as Youth A’s.
 Police Report: Youth B’s account for the police detective provided the same
information that was received from her interview with this consultant.
However, she further reported that she had knocked on the bathroom door to
talk to Youth B. When Youth B opened the door, she had a towel on and
showed Youth A her breasts. Youth B went to kiss Youth A, so Youth A
kissed her back. Youth A admitted to rubbing Youth A’s vagina over Youth A’s
underwear.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
12

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as there was not a
sufficient number of staff working to provide for the continual
needs, protection, and supervision of the youth. The two staff on
shift did not follow Youth A and Youth B’s safety plan as they
were occupied when Youth C and Youth F were fighting, leaving
Youth A and Youth B unattended.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0103005; CAP Approved 3/8/21
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
The facility is not forwarding incident reports to the youths Foster Care Worker.
INVESTIGATION:
During the above investigation the Foster Care Worker (FCW) for Youth A sent e-
mails indicating what incident reports were sent to her and when she received them.
It was noted that she had not received incident reports for all incidents involving
Youth A and the only incident reports she did receive she had to request from the
facility.
Documents Reviewed:
 E-mails from FCW to Therapist on 3/2/22: The FCW wrote that she was only
being provided with Incident Reports involving Youth A if she requested them.
 E-mails from FCW indicating an incident occurred with 12/5/21 and she was
notified on 12/15, an incident occurred on 1/12/22 and she was notified on
1/28, and incidents that occurred on 1/21/22, 1/22/22, 2/7/22, and 2/12/22 she
was notified on 2/25/22.
 E-mails from Quality Assurance Coordinator (QAC) to FCW: Summaries of
incidents were forwarded to the FCW on 12/15/21, 2/28/22, and 3/23/22.
 E-mail from QAC on 4/7/22 stated as of this date she sent all incidents except
for the 3/28/22 incident to the FCW.
 E-mail from Associate Director of Compliance (ADC): Their understanding of
this part of the contract has been “incident reports” referred to
restraint/seclusion events, which they have been making available to workers
“We have never been asked or expected to send copies of “all” incident
reports to workers, and it would be quite a significant task for us to forward
those reports directly to our clients’ assigned caseworkers.”
 Youth A’s incident reports were reviewed.
